title: A little help please
content:
Hi everyone, just signed up to this forum.  
I was looking through a design book I brought over the weekend and I was wondering if anyone out there would know the name of this font

Thanks

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110im_/http:/typophile.com/files/unknown-font_5418.jpg)

 [‹ Flight Exec logo font](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/typophile.com/node/39240 "Go to previous forum topic") [1960s font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/typophile.com/node/39230 "Go to next forum topic")
author: green11

comments.content:
Then, they both [are based on DIN](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17377). There’s a [DIN 17 SB (Rounded)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/din-17-sb/) available from Elsner+Flake that would be a good match, too.  
Or you wait until FontFont will release [Albert-Jan Pool](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Albert-Jan%252BPool)’s FF DIN Rounded … ;°)

<cite>Or you wait until FontFont will release Albert-Jan Pool’s FF DIN Rounded</cite>  
No, wait … that one will have a two-storey ‘a’, at least according to this [preview](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/www.fontblog.de/dialog-der-schrift-in-kiel). Makes sense, as FF DIN has it, too.

Wow big help thanks a million Florian.  
I’ll sit down later and have a good look through those links and see which one will work the best.

Thanks

Bryant is another rounded sans with a single-story a (as an alternate):  
 [http://processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20071120081110/http:/processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/index.html "http://processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/index.html")
